{{Infobox scientist | name = Lauriston Sale Taylor | image = LSTaylor.png | caption = Lauriston S. Taylor | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1902|6|1}} | birth_place = [[Brooklyn, New York]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2004|11|26|1902|6|1}} | death_place = {{nowrap|[[Mitchellville, Maryland]]}} | fields = [[Physicist]],
Radiation research scientist | work_institutions = [[Bell Laboratories]]
[[Memorial Hospital (New York City, New York)]]
[[National Bureau of Standards]] | alma_mater = [[Stevens Institute]]
[[Cornell University]] | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | known_for = }} '''Lauriston S. Taylor''' (1 June 1902 – 26 November 2004) was an American physicist known for his work in the field of radiation protection and measurement. ==Career== He established standards for X-ray radiation exposure for the first time in the 1920s, which eventually led to a group of government organizations that set the standards over the next 50 years. Taylor remained active in debates about radiation exposure into his 80s, often advocating the viewpoint that small doses of radiation were not important. ==Accolades== He served as president of the [[Health Physics Society]] (HPS) from 1958 to 1959. He was a recipient of the [[Medal of Freedom (1945)|Medal of Freedom]], and the Presidential [[Bronze Star]] (then the highest military award that could be given to a civilian).[[Health Physics Society]], [http://hps.org/aboutthesociety/people/inmemoriam/LauristonTaylor.html In Memoriam: Lauriston S. Taylor]. Retrieved 25 June 2014. ==Vignettes of early radiation workers== In 1977 the [[Food and Drug Administration]] of the [[U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]] initiated a series of 25 [[Interview|recorded interviews]] with early radiation workers to provide an historical overview of their research and discoveries primarily in the fields of [[medical physics]], [[radiation]], and [[radiobiology]]. Lauriston S. Taylor moderated the series and also was an interview subject.{{Citation | author1=Taylor, Lauriston S. (Lauriston Sale) | author2=Sauer, Kelly G | author3=Center for Devices and Radiological Health (U.S.) | title=Vignettes of early radiation workers : transcripts of the videotape series | publication-date=1984 | publisher=U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Public Health Service, Food and Drug Administration, Center for Devices and Radiological Health}} ===Interview subjects=== * Howard Andrews * Walter Binks, physicist and specialist in radiology * Carl Bjorn Braestrup * Austin M. Brues, physician [[United States National Research Council|National Research Council]] * [[Robley Evans]] * George Henny * Paul Henshaw, physician [[United States National Research Council|National Research Council]] * Norman Hilberry, "Mr. Scram", axe man at the first [[chain reaction]] for [[Chicago Pile 1]], Director of [[Argonne National Laboratory]], 1957-1961 * Lillian E. Jacobson, [[Physicist]], Radiotherapy Department and Laboratory Division of [[Montefiore Medical Center|Montefiore Hospital]], New York * [[Harold E. Johns]], Canadian [[medical physicist]] * [[George Laurence]], Canadian [[nuclear physicist]] * [[John H. Lawrence]], American physicist and physician, [[nuclear medicine]] pioneer * [[Herbert Parker (scientist)|Herbert M. Parker]], English born, American pioneer in medical [[radiation therapy]] and [[radiation safety]] * [[Edward Pochin|Sir Edward Eric Pochin]], British physician, specialist in [[ionizing radiation]] safety * [[Edith Quimby]], American [[medical researcher]] and [[physicist]], pioneer in [[nuclear medicine]] * John E. Rose, health physicist * [[Roberts Rugh]], Department of Radiology, Columbia University, directed research on the effects of ionizing radiation, served as senior medical consultant * Eric E. Smith, British specialist in the field of ionizing radiation * [[James Newell Stannard]], [[radiobiologist]], [[Pharmacologist]] and [[Physiologist]] at the [[National Institutes of Health]] * Lauriston Sale "Laurie" Taylor * E. Dale Trout, [[radiologist]], Professor Emeritus of [[Health physics|Radiological Physics]], [[Oregon State University]] * [[John G. Trump]], American [[high-voltage]] [[engineer]] and [[physicist]] * [[John Austin Victoreen|John Austin "Jack" Victoreen]], self-taught radio engineer, pioneer of radiation detection instruments * Samuel Reid Warren Jr., professor in [[electrical engineering]] at the [[University of Pennsylvania]] and radiation physicist * [[Shields Warren]], pioneer [[pathologist]] and [[expert]] in [[medical radiation]] * Marvin Martin Dixon Williams, pioneer in [[medical physics]], head of [[physics]] at the [[Mayo Clinic]] * Harold O. Wyckoff, pioneer in measurement of radiation and radiation protection standards ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Taylor, Lauriston S.}} [[Category:1902 births]] [[Category:2004 deaths]] [[Category:American physicists]] [[Category:Health physicists]] [[Category:Cornell University alumni]] [[Category:Radiation health effects]] [[Category:Radiation protection]] [[Category:Recipients of the Medal of Freedom]] [[Category:Health Physics Society]] [[Category:Bell Labs]] [[Category:National Institute of Standards and Technology]]

page.title: List of diseases spread by invertebrates

revision.text:
Invertebrates are very common vectors of disease. A vector is an organism which spreads disease from one host to another. Invertebrates spread bacterial, viral and protozoan pathogens by two main mechanisms. Either via their bite, as in the case of malaria spread by mosquitoes, or via their faeces, as in the case of Chagas' Disease spread by Triatoma bugs or epidemic typhus spread by human body lice. Many invertebrates are responsible for transmitting diseases. Mosquitoes are perhaps the best known invertebrate vector and transmit a wide range of tropical diseases including malaria, dengue fever and yellow fever. Another large group of vectors are flies. Sandfly species transmit the disease leishmaniasis, by acting as vectors for protozoan ''Leishmania'' species, and tsetse flies transmit protozoan trypansomes (''Trypanosoma brucei gambiense'' and ''Trypansoma brucei rhodesiense'') which cause African Trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness). Ticks and lice form another large group of invertebrate vectors. The bacterium ''Borrelia burgdorferi'', which causes Lyme Disease, is transmitted by ticks and members of the bacterial genus ''Rickettsia'' are transmitted by lice. For example, the human body louse transmits the bacterium ''Rickettsia prowazekii'' which causes epidemic typhus. Although invertebrate-transmitted diseases pose a particular threat on the continents of Africa, Asia and South America, there is one way of controlling invertebrate-borne diseases, which is by controlling the invertebrate vector. For example, one way of controlling malaria is to control the mosquito vector through the use of mosquito nets, which prevent mosquitoes from coming into contact with humans. This is a '''list of diseases spread by invertebrates'''. == Diseases == {| class="wikitable" |- !width="100" | Disease !width="100" | Vector !Causative organism !Host !Symptoms !Area !Treatment |- |[[African horse sickness]]||[[Culicoides|Culicoid midge]]||''Orbivirus'' (virus)||[[Equidae|Equid]]s||Fever, lung, heart or mucous membrane symptoms.||Europe, Africa||Vaccination |- |[[Babesiosis]]||[[Tick]]||''[[Babesia]]'' (protozoan)||Humans, rodents, dogs, cattle||Fever, [[hemolytic anemia]], chills, sweating, [[thrombocytopenia]]||South Europe, Central United States||Antibiotics |- |[[Bluetongue disease]]||[[Culicoides|Culicoid midge]]||''Orbivirus'' (virus)||Cattle, sheep||Fever, salivation, swelling of face and tongue||Europe, Africa||Vaccination |- |[[Chagas disease]] (American trypanosomiasis)||Various assassin bugs of subfamily [[Triatominae]]||''[[Trypanosoma cruzi]]'' (protozoan)||||Mild symptoms, then chronic heart or brain inflammation||Central and South America||Antiparasitic drugs; {{refimprove|date=August 2013}}
[[Image:Mindsetcorporatelogo.jpg|Thumb|right]] '''Mindset Network''' is a non-profit organisation formed in 2002 to educate and improve health in [[South Africa]]. It develops, sources, distributes and uses digital content. Its multimedia content is distributed via broadcast television, IP based satellite [[datacast]], the web, distributable media (hard drives, DVDs and CDs) and mobile networks.
== Programmes == Mindset has 3 programmes. Learn and Cabanga are for secondary and primary schools respectively, while Health is for the South African health sector. Mindset is developing a Livelihoods channel for developing the skills of out-of-school youth.
=== Learn === {{infobox_software | name = Mindset Learn | logo = | website = [https://learn.mindset.co.za/] }} Mindset Learn, the original programme, is for Grades 10 to 12 at South African high schools. It covers Mathematics, Physical Science, English and Information Technology.
=== Cabanga === {{infobox_software |name = Mindset Cabanga |logo = [[Image:Mindsetcabangalogo.jpg]] |website = [http://www.mindset.co.za/cabanga www.mindset.co.za/cabanga] }} Mindset Cabanga, with support from [[USAID]], is a programme for Grades 4 and 5 covering Mathematics, Natural Science and Technology.
=== Health === {{infobox_software |name = Mindset Health |logo = <!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[Image:Mindsethealthlogo.jpg]] --> |website = [http://www.mindset.co.za/health www.mindset.co.za/health] }} Mindset Health is about treating [[HIV/AIDS]]. The programme reaches patients in clinic and hospital waiting rooms, and health care providers.
== External links == *[http://www.mindset.co.za Mindset Network]
[[Category:Medical and health organisations based in South Africa]] [[Category:Educational technology non-profits]] [[Category:Health education]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS organizations]] [[Category:Information technology organizations]]

{{Orphan|date=February 2009}} '''Mobile Crisis''', or '''Mobile Crisis Rapid Response Team (MCRRT)''', is a [[mental health]] service in the [[United States]] and [[Canada]] (typically operated by hospital or community mental health agency) which services the community by providing immediate response emergency mental health evaluations. Evaluations are often requested by hospital [[Emergency department|emergency rooms]], but can also be requested by [[Intensive care medicine|ICUs]], CCUs, jails, nursing homes, police, or EMS. These services are often available on a 24-hour basis.
Mobile Crisis evaluations are typically requested due to a reasonable expectation of self-inflicted harm to the client, but can also be requested due to a reasonable expectation of the client's intent to harm another person. In addition to Suicidal/Homicidal Ideation or gestures, an assessment may be requested due to a person exhibiting signs of psychosis, grave alien, or altered mental status believed not to have an organic etiology. Criteria for requesting a Mobile Crisis assessment varies depending upon individual mental health agencies and entities that regulate mental health services, as well as statues created via legislative assemblies. An assessment may be requested for situations involving [[alcohol (drug)|alcohol]] and drugs (where there is not a mental health component), or "routine" evaluations requested where there is not a reasonable expectation of harm to the client or another individual, as long as psychopathology is not otherwise ruled out.
The Mobile Crisis clinician has typically obtained her/his [[Master's degree]] in a mental health-related field (such as [[social work]], [[mental health counseling]], or [[counseling psychology]]). The clinician performs the evaluation based on standard models of mental status examination (alert and oriented, mood, thought process, affect, etc.), and assigns a [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders|DSM-5]] (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of the American Psychiatric Association, Fifth Edition) diagnosis if this falls within their scope of practice. After completing the evaluation, the clinician makes a disposition, or placement, decision for the client. Placements can include involuntary in-patient hospitalization, voluntary in-patient hospitalization, or discharge to home with out-patient referrals. Following disposition, the Mobile Crisis unit can be expected to follow up with the client within a few days.
==External links== http://dhss.delaware.gov/dhss/dsamh/crisis_intervention.html
*[http://www.nyc.gov/html/doh/html/cis/cis_mct.shtml New York City Mobile Crisis Team]
[[Category:Mental health in the United States]]

{{redirect|NZSP|the airport at Amundsen–Scott South Pole Station|Jack F. Paulus Skiway}}
The '''New Zealand Society of Physiotherapists''' ('''NZSP''') is a [[Professional association|professional body]] of [[physiotherapists]] in New Zealand. Membership of the society is optional, but demonstrates that a particular practitioner upholds certain standards including adherence to a code of conduct. Individuals who meet certain criteria may indicate their membership by using the letters MNZSP or FNZSP after their names.
== History == The society was established in 1950.<ref name="pamphlet1">Your Professional Society : The New Zealand Society of Physiotherapists Inc - Pamphlet</ref>
== Membership classes == *Member: Must be a New Zealand registered physiotherapist. A member may use the letters 'MNZSP' to indicate their membership. *Associate: This is the class held by a student who wishes to join the society. *Affiliate: A physiotherapy assistant working under supervision of a registered physiotherapist may hold this class. *Fellow: This class is bestowed upon members at the discretion of the society.<ref name="fellow">[http://www.otago.ac.nz/news/news/2002/25-07-02_press_release.html Footnote indicating Robin McKenzie's Honorary Fellow status]</ref> Those with this class of membership may use the letters FNZSP.
== Motto == The motto, in [[Māori language|Māori]], is "kia akotahi tatou, kia kotahi ra" (let's learn and grow together).
== Branches == The society is made up of branches which represent geographical regions around the country. Each member of the society belongs to and is represented by a branch for the region in which they reside.
The branches are: *[[Auckland]] *[[Canterbury, New Zealand|Canterbury]] *[[Hawkes Bay]] *Middle Districts *Nelson and Marlborough *[[Northland Region|Northland]] *[[North Shore City|North Shore]] *[[Otago]] *[[Southland Region|Southland]] *[[Waikato]] and [[Bay of Plenty]] *[[Wellington]]
== Special interest groups == The society also supports a number of groups of practitioners who are interested in particular specialities within the profession. Membership of a special interest group is optional.
The following special interest groups exist: *Cardiothoracic *Continence and Women's Health *Hand Therapists *[[Neurology]] *New Zealand Manipulative Physiotherapists Association *New Zealand Private Physiotherapy Association *New Zealand Sports and Orthopaedic Physiotherapy Association *[[Occupational Health]] *[[Paediatric]] *Physiotherapy Acupuncture Association of New Zealand *Physiotherapy for the Older Adult *[[Stress Management]] and Related Therapies
==See also== * [[Physical therapy#New Zealand|Physiotherapy]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.nzsp.org.nz NZSP Website]
[[Category:Medical and health organisations based in New Zealand]] [[Category:Physiotherapy organisations|Physiotherapists]]

{{Multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=June 2015}} {{underlinked|date=June 2015}} }}
'''OSMECON''' is a pan-India Undergraduate medical conference held annually by [[Osmania Medical College]] and its associate hospitals. It is a three-day-long event usually held in August every year.
Designed as a special platform presented by Osmania Medical College to promote undergraduate talent, it instills scientific reasoning and reinforces the value of medical research. Started in 2010 to share medical research done by undergraduates, OSMECON has grown into a special event to showcase, learn, share and gain knowledge.It aims to inculcate a healthy and competitive atmosphere of learning medicine through discussion and research.Under the constant guidance of faculty members, the inaugural edition took place in 2010.The conference was initially restricted to Indian Medical Undergraduates. In its 5th edition held in 2014, the conference witnessed the participation of Foreign Medical Undergraduates. The 9th edition of OSMECON is scheduled to be held on 10,11,12 August 2018.
== OSMECON-2010 ==
* OSMECON started in 2010 as a one-day event restricted to the state. * '''Dr.C.Raghu''',<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.drraghu.com/profile/|title=Dr.Raghu Cardiologist - Professional Synopsis|work=Dr Raghu|access-date=2018-05-31|language=en-US}}</ref> '''Interventional Cardiologist and Director – Prime Hospitals, Hyderabad''' graced OSMECON as the Chief guest. * It was a single day event with case, paper and poster presentation as the main events with 40 delegates.
== OSMECON-2011 == The conference reached out to other medical colleges in erstwhile Andhra Pradesh. It was a two-day event conducted on the 25,26 August 2011 with 100 delegates.The following were introduced for the first time–
* Poster presentation on [[Nanotechnology education|Nanotechnology]] & [[Robotics]] in medicine * MedQuiz on [[Antimicrobial resistance]] * Seminar on Research Methodology-by [https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/mendu-vishnu-vardhana-rao-named-director-national-institute-of-medical-statistics/article9995315.ece '''Dr.VishnuVardan'''] Rao, NIN, Hyderabad.
== OSMECON-2012 == '''Dr.B.Sesi Kiran''', Former Director of NIN gave a lecture on Research Methodology and '''Dr.Sreekanth Vemula,'''<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://hyderabad.apollohospitals.com/dr-vemula-sreekanth/|title=Dr.Vemula Sreekanth -|access-date=2018-05-31|language=en-US}}</ref> Eminent Neurophysician, graced the event.
It was a 3-day event held from 31 August-2 September with 400 delegates.
The highlight of the conference was the introduction of workshops for undergraduate medical students.
* Basic Life Support Skills, * Basic Surgical Skills, * Safe Shift of Trauma victim.
== OSMECON-2013 ==
* '''Bharat Ratna Dr.A.P.J.[[A. P. J. Abdul Kalam|Abdul Kalam]]''', Former President of India graced the conference and made the event magnificent and memorable for everyone. * '''Dr.Arun Tiwari''', DRDO Scientist, adjunct professor HCU and co-author of several books with Dr.Kalam also spoke about "Squaring the circle - 7 steps to Indian Renaissance". * It was a 4-day event with the participation of over 700 delegates and had 3 workshops on: Basic Life Support Skills, Basic Surgical Skills, Obstetrics and Neonatology.
== OSMECON-2014 == '''Dr.Ch.Mohan Rao,''' Director CCMB & '''Dr.Kalpagam Polasa''', former Director of NIN inaugurated the event and spoke of the research scenario in the country.
'''Dr.Gullapalli Nageswara Rao''', Founder of LV Prasad Eye Hospital, delivered a guest lecture.
Theme of the conference : '''Mental Health Awareness'''
There were 800 delegates with 7 from Nepal. The following events were introduced:
* MedTech * Panel Discussion * Medical Dumbcharades * Medical Short films
== OSMECON-2015 == '''Padma Shri Dr.[[Kakarla Subba Rao]],''' internationally renowned radiologist and Father of Radiology in India, inaugurated the event.
'''Padma Shri Dr.[[Lavu Narendranath|L.Narendranath]]''', eminent Orthopaedic surgeon delivered a guest lecture on 'IT Solutions in Health Care'.
Theme of Poster Presentation : '''3-D Printing in Medicine, Novel Drug Delivery Systems'''
It was a 3-day event with the participation of over 1000 delegates & had 5 workshops on:
1) Basic Life Support Skills,
2) Basic Surgical Skills,
3) ECG Interpretation
4) Basic Medical imaging
5) Obstetrics & Neonatology,
6) Orthopaedic skills and Trauma Care.
== OSMECON-2016 == '''Padmashri Dr. A.[[A. G. K. Gokhale|Gopala Krishna Gokhale]]''' (Cardiothoracic Surgeon, First Minimal Access Heart Surgeon & First Heart-Kidney combined Transplant Surgeon) delivered the Inaugural Address.
'''Dr. G.V.Ramana Rao'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://eindia.eletsonline.com/2012/dr-g-v-ramana-rao-executive-partner-emergency-medicine-learning-centre-emlc-research/|title=http://eindia.eletsonline.com/2012/dr-g-v-ramana-rao-executive-partner-emergency-medicine-learning-centre-emlc-research/|website=eindia.eletsonline.com|access-date=2018-05-31}}</ref> (Executive Partner, Head of Emergency Medicine Learning Centre (EMLC) and Research division at GVK-EMRI) was the Guest of Honour
'''Dr. G.Jagdishwar Goud''',<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.yashodahospitals.com/doctor/secunderabad/robotic-sciences/dr-jagdishwar-goud/|title=Dr Jagdishwar Goud {{!}} Best Surgical Oncologist in Hyderabad {{!}} Yashoda Hospitals|work=Yashoda Hospitals|access-date=2018-05-31|language=en-US}}</ref> renowned Surgical Oncologist and Robotic Surgeon spoke about trends in Robotic Surgery.
'''Dr. M.Pari Plavi''', distinguished alumna of Osmania Medical College, former Professor and Head of Department of Anatomy at [[Osmania Medical College]], Founder-Convener of OSMECON, discussed the Neuroscience of Adolescence and Meditation.
Theme of Poster Presentation : '''Cancer Immunotherapy, Personalised Medicine'''
There were about 1100 delegates attending from all over the country.
== OSMECON-2017 == '''Dr.K.Srinath Reddy''',<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://phfi.org/member/prof-k-srinath-reddy/|title=Prof. K. Srinath Reddy – Public Health Foundation of India|website=phfi.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-31}}</ref> President of Public Health Foundation of India delivered the inaugural address.
'''Dr.Patanjali Dev Naya'''r,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/patanjali-dev-nayar-705aa440/|title=Dr.Patanjali Dev Nayar|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}{{dead link|date=November 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Regional Advisor, Disability & Injury Prevention, WHO SEARO delivered a lecture on "Manoeuvring crossroads to human sexuality".
Theme of the conference : '''Adolescent & Reproductive Health'''
Over 1400 delegates participated in the eighth edition, with over 120 international delegates, taking the event to a bigger stage. Two new workshops were introduced:
1) Chest Sounds Interpretation
2) Forensic Autopsy
== OSMECON-2018 == The 9th edition of Osmecon is scheduled to be held on 10,11,12 August at [[Osmania Medical College]], Hyderabad. The conference will add 3 new workshops to its list-
* Arterial Blood Gas Analysis * Interactive Genomics * Soft Skills
== EVENTS ==
=== DAY 1 WORKSHOPS === Basic Life Support
Basic Surgical Skills
Obstetrics and Neonatology
Emergency and Trauma Care
Research Methodology
Chest Sound Interpretation
Arterial Blood Gas Analysis
Forensic Medicine-Autopsy
ECG Interpretatiom
Imaging & Radiology
Soft Skills
Interactive Genomics
=== DAY 2&3 : COMPETITIONS === The events held are as under
'''Case presentation :''' An excellent opportunity to share an interesting case with peers and professionals alike in the medical field.
'''Paper presentation :''' A platform for young researchers to showcase their talent. Research done by undergraduates in any medical field is accepted.
'''Poster presentation :''' In this session delegates present posters about the most happening topics in the field of medicine.
'''Medical Symposium'''
'''MedQuiz (Medical Quiz)'''
'''Dare to Diagnose (Case Diagnosis)'''
'''Art Attack (Sketching)'''
'''ShutterMedics (Photography)'''
'''Diogenes Club (Debate)'''
'''Medventure'''
'''Graphilia'''
'''Invictus'''
'''Spellbee'''
'''Medical Dumbcharades'''
References {{Reflist}} <ref>http://www.knowafest.com/2014/08/osmecon-2014-osmania-medical-college-medical-college-festival-hyderabad.html</ref>
<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.abdulkalam.com/kalam/jsp/display_content_front.jsp?menuid=28&menuname=Speeches+%2F+Lectures&linkid=68&linkname=Recent&content=2368&columnno=0&starts=0&menu_image# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2015-06-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150619202759/http://www.abdulkalam.com/kalam/jsp/display_content_front.jsp?menuid=28&menuname=Speeches+%2F+Lectures&linkid=68&linkname=Recent&content=2368&columnno=0&starts=0&menu_image# |archive-date=2015-06-19 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox Organization |name = OII-Chinese
國際陰陽人組織 — 中文版 |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |abbreviation = Oii-Chinese |motto = |formation = 8 November 2008 |type = [[NGO]] |status = |purpose = [[Intersex]] human rights |headquarters = |location = |region_served = East asia |membership = |language = |leader_title = |leader_name = |main_organ = |affiliations = [[Organisation Intersex International]] |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://oii.tw/ oii.tw] |remarks = }} Founded by [[Hiker Chiu]] in 2008, '''Oii-Chinese''' (國際陰陽人組織 — 中文版) is an [[intersex]] advocacy and support group and the Chinese language affiliate of [[Organisation Intersex International]]. Oii-Chinese is active in Taiwan, Hong Kong, and other areas in East Asia.{{cite web| url = http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/feat/archives/2013/11/27/2003577754/ | title = Neither here, nor there | work = [[Taipei Times]] | date = November 27, 2013}} == Mission and activities == The organisation aims to end "normalising" surgeries on intersex children, promote awareness of intersex issues, and improve government recognition of gender. Chiu says that surgical "normalisation" practices began in Taiwan in 1953. As part of this mission, Chiu started a "free hugs with intersex" campaign at Taipei's LGBT Pride Parade in 2010. The organisation also gives lectures and lobbies government.{{cite news | url = http://www.lihpao.com/?action-viewnews-itemid-136232 | title = 擁抱陰陽人 系列2：停止矯正手術 陰陽兒不是異形 | work = Lihpao Daily | date = 23 December 2013}}{{cite news | url = http://www.gaystarnews.com/article/taiwan-allows-legal-gender-changes-without-transitioning091213 | title = Taiwan to allow legal gender changes without transitioning | work = [[Gay Star News]] | date = 9 December 2013}}{{cite web | url = http://www.libertytimes.com.tw/2013/new/nov/3/today-o2.htm | title = Germany recognises gender 'X' | work = [[Liberty Times]] | date = November 3, 2013}}{{cite web | url = http://blog.rti.org.tw/english/2011/01/20/intersex-hiker-chius-story/ | title = Intersex: Hiker Chiu’s story | work = [[Radio Taiwan International]] | date = January 20, 2011}} == Affiliations == Oii-Chinese is affiliated to [[Organisation Intersex International]] and a member of the [[International Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans and Intersex Association]].{{cite web | url = http://ilgatheraisingphoenix.blogspot.com.au/2013/03/intersex-and-transmen-life-story.html | title = Intersex and Transmen Life Story | work = The 5th ILGA Asia Conference | date = March 30, 2013}}{{cite web | url = http://ilga2012.org/segundo-foro-mundial-intersex/ | language = es | title = Segundo Foro Mundial Intersex | work = [[ILGA]] | date = December 11, 2012}} In 2015, Chiu was elected to the board of the [[International Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans and Intersex Association]] to represent ILGA Asia.{{cite web | title = Board | url = http://ilga.org/about-us/board/ | work = [[International Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans and Intersex Association]] | accessdate = 2017-01-12}} == See also == * [[Intersex human rights]] * [[Intersex rights in China]] == References == {{Reflist|2}} == External links == *{{official website|http://oii.tw}} *{{Facebook|oii.chinese}} {{intersex}} [[Category:Intersex medical and health organizations]] [[Category:Intersex support groups]] [[Category:Intersex rights organizations]] [[Category:Intersex rights in China]]

page.title: Ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament

revision.text:
{{Infobox medical condition | name = {{PAGENAME}} | image = Gray302.png | caption = Posterior longitudinal ligament (running vertically in the center) in the thoracic region. | ICD10 = {{ICD10|M48.8}} | MeSH = D017887 | GeneReviewsName = | GeneReviewsName2 = | GeneReviewsName3 = | GeneReviewsName4 = | GeneReviewsName5 = | GeneReviewsName6 = | GeneReviewsName7 = }}
'''Ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament''' ('''OPLL''') is a process of [[fibrosis]], [[calcification]], and [[ossification]] of the [[posterior longitudinal ligament]] of the spine, that may involve the spinal dura.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/474019573|title=Handbook of neurosurgery|last=Greenberg|first=Mark|date=2006-01-01|publisher=Thieme|year=|isbn=1588904571|location=|pages=|oclc=474019573}}</ref> Once considered a disorder unique to people of Asian heritage, it is now recognized as an uncommon disorder in a variety of patients with [[myelopathy]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Belanger|first=Theodore|year=2005|title=Ossification of the Posterior Longitudinal Ligament|url=http://journals.lww.com/jbjsjournal/pages/default.aspx|journal=Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery|volume=87|pages=610–615|via=Proquest}}</ref>
== Causes == The causes of OPLL are unknown. However, genetic and environmental factors appear to play a role in pathogenesis.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":0" /> OPLL may also be associated with [[diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis]]<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Belanger|first=T. A.|last2=Rowe|first2=D. E.|date=2001-07-01|title=Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis: musculoskeletal manifestations|journal=The Journal of the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons|volume=9|issue=4|pages=258–267|issn=1067-151X|pmid=11476536}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Meyer|first=Paul|year=1999|title=diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis in the cervical spine|url=http://journals.lww.com/corr/Abstract/1999/02000/Diffuse_Idiopathic_Skeletal_Hyperostosis_in_the.6.aspx|journal=Clinical Orthopaedics & Related Research|volume=359|pages=|via=}}</ref>
== Diagnosis == Myeolography, including post-myelographic CT is likely the most effective imaging study an accurate diagnosis.<ref name=":0" />
== Treatment == Surgical management options include extensive cervical [[laminectomy]] with or without an additional posterior [[arthrodesis]], anterior decompression and arthrodesis, and posterior cervical laminoplasty.<ref name=":2" /> Treatment decisions can be made based on a grading systems devised by Hirabayashi et al.,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hirabayashi|first=K.|last2=Watanabe|first2=K.|last3=Wakano|first3=K.|last4=Suzuki|first4=N.|last5=Satomi|first5=K.|last6=Ishii|first6=Y.|date=1983-10-01|title=Expansive open-door laminoplasty for cervical spinal stenotic myelopathy|journal=Spine|volume=8|issue=7|pages=693–699|issn=0362-2436|pmid=6420895}}</ref> supplemented by the Nurick myelopathy classification system.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=NURJCK|first=S.|date=1972-01-01|title=THE PATHOGENESIS OF THE SPINAL CORD DISORDER ASSOCIATED WITH CERVICAL SPONDYLOSIS|url=https://academic.oup.com/brain/article-lookup/doi/10.1093/brain/95.1.87|journal=Brain|language=en|volume=95|issue=1|pages=87–100|doi=10.1093/brain/95.1.87|issn=0006-8950}}</ref>
== Prognosis == Most patients suffer from only mild symptoms.<ref name=":0" /> Symptoms typically last approximately 13 months.<ref name=":0" /> Of patients without myelopathy at initial presentation, only 29% of them will develop myelopathy within 30 years.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Matsunaga|first=Shunji|last2=Sakou|first2=Takashi|last3=Taketomi|first3=Eiji|last4=Komiya|first4=Setsuro|date=2004-03-01|title=Clinical course of patients with ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament: a minimum 10-year cohort study|url=http://thejns.org/doi/abs/10.3171/spi.2004.100.3.0245|journal=Journal of Neurosurgery: Spine|volume=100|issue=3|pages=245–248|doi=10.3171/spi.2004.100.3.0245|issn=1547-5654}}</ref>
== Epidemiology == The age range of patients with OPLL is from 32 to 81 years (mean = 53), with a male predominance.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Choi|first=Byung-Wan|last2=Song|first2=Kyung-Jin|last3=Chang|first3=Han|title=Ossification of the Posterior Longitudinal Ligament: A Review of Literature|url=https://synapse.koreamed.org/DOIx.php?id=10.4184/asj.2011.5.4.267|journal=Asian Spine Journal|volume=5|issue=4|doi=10.4184/asj.2011.5.4.267|pmc=3230657|pmid=22164324}}</ref> Prevalence is higher in those of Japanese or Asian ancestry (2-3.5%) <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tsuyama|first=N.|date=1984-04-01|title=Ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament of the spine|journal=Clinical Orthopaedics and Related Research|issue=184|pages=71–84|issn=0009-921X|pmid=6423334}}</ref> and rarer in other racial groups (0.16%).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wang|first=Michael Y.|last2=Thambuswamy|first2=Michael|date=2011-03-01|title=Ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament in non-Asians: demographic, clinical, and radiographic findings in 43 patients|journal=Neurosurgical Focus|volume=30|issue=3|pages=E4|doi=10.3171/2010.12.FOCUS10277|issn=1092-0684|pmid=21434820}}</ref> Schizophrenia patients in Japan may have as high as 20% incidence.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Matsunaga|first=Shunji|last2=Koga|first2=Hiroaki|last3=Kawabata|first3=Naoya|last4=Kawamura|first4=Ichiro|last5=Otusji|first5=Masaki|last6=Imakiire|first6=Takanori|last7=Komiya|first7=Setsuro|date=2008-06-01|title=Ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament in dizygotic twins with schizophrenia: a case report|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.3109/s10165-008-0036-1|journal=Modern Rheumatology|volume=18|issue=3|pages=277–280|doi=10.3109/s10165-008-0036-1|issn=1439-7595}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
